Key Arguments: The Bill is an assault on free speech and entrenches censorship.
It infringes on the implied freedom of political communication.
Lawmaking over fundamental rights should not be delegated to private entities.
The Bill favors censorship over free expression.
Existing laws already address misinformation without pre-censorship.
The Bill provides no recourse for affected users and punishes only the failure to censor.
The Bill's definitions of misinformation are vague and allow for broad censorship.
Notable Quotes: The proposed bill is a needless assault on free speech in Australia which will entrench the censorious power of big tech over Australians and give it the force of law.
The Bill is purported to balance combating misinformation and disinformation against the freedom of expression. But this balancing is in name only.

The Bill demands that misinformation codes require participants in the digital platform industry to implement measures to prevent or respond to misinformation and disinformation on digital platform services.
